I understand that the parliament would not have the power constitutionally to prevent the executive from carrying out its treaty negotiation or treaty making role, and that is acknowledged. Only if the text, and not the object or purpose of a treaty, were specifically objected to might parliamentary approval be withheld.

The benefits of that sort of approach are several. If the government gets approval prior to negotiating and concluding a treaty, then Australia will be able to move quickly to ratify and implement the treaty. Contentious provisions can be identified early and, if necessary, have reservations placed on them. This proposed procedure would provide an opportunity to obtain greater input from the public and interested groups, which may lead to greater community support when the treaty is later translated into domestic legislation.

This suggested procedure does not come without its drawbacks. Since Australia could not obtain parliamentary approval of the text of a treaty until the final stage, Australia's effectiveness during negotiations might be weakened. This is a significant disadvantage, of course, in the case of multilateral agreements but it is less so with bilateral agreements. In my view, it is worth taking the time now to examine this proposal and related matters in order to find some balance.

I support the concerns expressed by the present government to respond to the demand by Australians for more say in the treaty making process. The government should ensure not only that Australians take part in the process but that consultation is appropriate, extensive and thorough. Without this Australia cannot take full advantage of all the opportunities to form links overseas, including those that will benefit local industry.

I hope that when the government assesses the progress of its reform to the treaty making process it takes my comments into account in the constructive way in which they are intended, and gives consideration to the points I have tried to make.

As I have already noted, constitutional power to enter into treaties for Australia rests with the government and cannot be assumed by the parliament. Many Australians are confident that the present government will not use this power to enact laws properly within the domain of the states and territories, nor ratify a treaty in deliberate disregard of widespread community concern about it. I await the early fulfilment by the government of the undertaking made to me in the chamber in May of this year on its behalf by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Southcott, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this omnibus bill, the Foreign Affairs and Trade Legislation Amendment Bill 1997, I am going to deal with each of the amendments as there is no overall theme which governs the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The first amendment is the amendment to the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994. The background to that act is that Australia signed the chemical weapons convention on 13 January 1993, ratified it in May 1994 and subsequently passed the act. In the original drafting of the act there was no provision made for observers from a challenge country to be granted diplomatic immunity and privileges when they were visiting a country. The amendment is to govern a situation where a challenge country may determine that a country is producing more than threshold amounts of certain chemicals and may request access to visit the facilities which are producing those chemicals.

It would be extremely unlikely that Australia would ever be challenged under the chemical weapons convention. It would be extremely unlikely that there would be an inspection team that would come to Australia to investigate a breach of the chemical weapons convention. Nevertheless, this amendment will extend the privileges and immunities to the observers from the challenging country.

The main part of the bill amends the International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1963. It deals with an act that is 34 years old and there are a number of amendments made. The amendments to that act will tighten the definition of an international organisation for the purpose of defining privileges and immunities. Generally, the privileges and immunities will extend to representatives of an international organisation who are involved in their official capacity.

It will also allow for representatives of international organisations to be subject to ordinary Australian law—criminal and civil law, property law—and to be able to own property and so on. That means Australia will only be granting the privileges and immunities which are required by international law. The amendment is necessary to keep pace with the increasing number of international organisations. It also allows for things like sales tax exemptions for international organisations which are headquartered in Australia.

Another amendment allows the regulations regarding the international organisations to come into force when the actual treaty comes into force. It was necessary to amend the Acts Interpretation Act to deal with an anomaly there.

The amendment also gives effect to certain obligations. It will extend privileges and immunities to international law tribunals. As I have said before, it will provide sales tax exemptions for international organisations that are headquartered in Australia. At present there are only two, the Commission for Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources in Hobart and the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna in Canberra. As a South Australian, I wonder why they did not headquarter that in Port Lincoln.

The sales tax exemptions will have a negligible financial impact. The one‐off direct cost to revenue is likely to be about $5,000 to $10,000, and there will also be a net annual cost of $2,000 to $5,000. That will be more than outweighed by the revenue that would be gained from Australians gaining employment at the international organisations and the international organisations buying our goods and services. Again, the impact from any international organisation which does establish their headquarters in Australia in the future will be positive.

At this point I might just say something on Australia's role in international disarmament. It is worth noting that Australia has been a leading player in international disarmament in relation to weapons of mass destruction, chemical weapons and also antipersonnel landmines. Last year the government was successful in concluding the comprehensive test ban treaty—in salvaging that treaty—and in September last year having it voted for overwhelmingly at the United Nations General Assembly. It is also worth noting the appointment of the Australians Dr John Gee, from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Richard Butler, a former diplomat, to head up international bodies on disarmament.

In the area of antipersonnel landmines Australia has contributed to the campaign to end the use of landmines in warfare. In April 1996 Australia indicated it would support the global ban on the production, stockpiling, use and transfer of these weapons. It is worth noting that Australia does not manufacture landmines, and it does not export landmines. We still do have an existing stock of landmines, which are used for training and research. As many members would know, the Australian Defence Force has a number of units with expertise in the clearing of landmines, and that was especially visible in our peacekeeping operations in Cambodia.

BREAK.PARA: Regarding weapons of mass proliferation, in September 1996 the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty was endorsed at the UN General Assembly, and the Canberra Commission, which was initiated by the previous Prime Minister, delivered its recommendations to the current government. Those recommendations, especially relating to the transparency of nuclear weapons and to delivery systems, have been sent to every government, and the Australian government has recommended that they consider those recommendations. It appears that they have had some effect, in that they were picked up by presidents Clinton and Yeltsin at the third START meeting in Helsinki this year.

Dealing with the amendment to the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation (Safeguards) Act, Australia signed the nuclear non‐proliferation treaty in 1970. It was actually signed by the Gorton government. The act in 1987 gave effect to Australia's obligations under the non‐proliferation treaty and gave effect to Australia's obligations under the safeguards of the International Atomic Energy Agency. It also dealt with things like setting up the ASO—the Australian Safeguards Office—and so on.

Since then, though, the lesson of the Gulf War has been that Iraq was able to have clandestine nuclear weapons which had not been detected by the International Atomic Energy Agency. One of the problems was that the declarations were not made when uranium and nuclear material for energy purposes was transferred to contribute to nuclear devices.

The IAEA has improved the safeguards and introduced a new protocol which is going to come into effect in Australia early next year. The practical effect of this will be that Lucas Heights is likely to be subject to increased international inspections. The uranium mines in Australia, and possibly Maralinga as well, are likely to be subject at least to declarations and perhaps international inspections. The Australian Safeguards Office has reported that the uranium mines and Lucas Heights have no objection to this international scrutiny and the stricter regime that will follow it.

The last amendment is an amendment to the Passports Act to expand the area dealing with the making of false statements in relation to passport applications. It adds the concept of recklessness in terms of people making false statements. As I said before, this omnibus bill is mainly a technical bill dealing with amending certain pieces of legislation. It really just tidies up some areas that were overlooked in the previous acts. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity of joining in the debate on this important bill, the Foreign Affairs and Trade Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 , currently before the Committee. This bill, as has been pointed out by other speakers, is an omnibus bill and it seeks to amend a number of acts of this parliament, namely the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994, the International Organizations (Privilege and Immunities) Act 1963, the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation (Safeguards) Act of 1987 and the Passports Act 1938. Two acts are also affected by government amendments. One is the Consular Fees Act 1955 and, again, the International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I want to take this opportunity of congratulating the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), his Parliamentary Secretary (Mr Andrew Thomson) and, indeed, the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer), on the white paper on foreign and trade policy which was released only a short time ago. This paper has been treated with adulation widely in the community. It is the first time that any government has brought down a paper on Australian trade and foreign policy. I believe that in the past trade and foreign policy has been treated in an ad hoc way, rather than in the focused way as outlined by the white paper delivered by the minister. It is important to note that the government will act in the national interest, be pragmatic and hard‐headed, aiming of course, to improve the security of jobs and the standard of living of all Australians.

The government has pointed out that it recognises that Australia has global interests which require an active foreign and trade policy of broad scope, and that within this framework Asia and the Pacific will be our highest priority, although not, of course, our only priority. The document is a declaration of commitment to the region. Most importantly, the document indicates that the government, in its administration of this area, will place great importance on further developing bilateral arrangements as a means of advancing our interests, not as an alternative to multilateral arrangements but as the basic building block of our foreign and trade policy strategies.

I believe that the government, the parliamentary secretary, and indeed both ministers, ought to be congratulated on that particular document which I believe will be a blueprint for foreign policy matters in this country for many years to come—regardless of what party happens to be in office. I am confident, however, that the coalition will remain in office for many years. The way in which this white paper has been broadly accepted—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you smiled then, Peter.

—I am smiling in the sense that I looked at your face and you seem to have an unrealistic expectation of getting elected next time. Obviously the Labor Party will not be elected. The point I am making is that the white paper on foreign and trade policy is a document which is not designed to be a partisan document. It is a document which is a blueprint for the future. I believe that great credit should be extended to those in the government responsible for it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned, however, the bill currently before the chamber is an omnibus bill which seeks to make changes to a number of bills. It is really quite interesting to see that in Australia these days we seem to be changing legislation often through omnibus bills rather than through individual amendment bills with respect to separate pieces of legislation. I suppose that in a sense, legislatively speaking, this is quite an efficient means of dealing with this matter and I am certainly not about to criticise that this morning.

The major amendments will extend to observers the same standard diplomatic privileges and immunities provided to inspectors carrying out challenge inspections under the chemical weapons convention; will allow regulations relating to an international organisation to come into force at the same time as the treaty establishing the organisation comes into force for Australia; will tighten the eligibility criteria for international organisations and people connected with those organisations to which Australia accords privileges and immunities; will enable specific privileges and immunities to be extended to international tribunals in accordance with Australia's treaty obligations; will implement the provisions of a protocol between the International Atomic Energy Agency and Australia to provide for expanded declarations of nuclear items and access to additional locations where nuclear material is customarily used; and will add the concept of recklessness in the offence of making a false statement in a passport application or in support of an application.

BREAK.PARA: I would think these particular matters included in the omnibus bill currently before the chamber should be considered to be non‐contentious. I believe that they are very positive changes and changes which will achieve strong support throughout the Australian community.

It is important to note briefly that the proposed alteration to the Consular Fees Act 1955 will expand the categories of persons who can be authorised to authenticate documents and charge the prescribed fees to include locally engaged staff overseas. The amendment is expected to result in improved and more flexible delivery of consular functions overseas, which should reduce the cost to the government providing those services. It is also consistent with the recommendations of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee report in June 1997 on consular services, Helping Australians abroad: a review of the Australian government's consular services. The amendment to the International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Act is of a technical nature only.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs pointed out in his second reading speech that Australia was going to have increased training for consuls and honorary consuls. I suppose that gives me a brief opportunity to say how impressed I am with many of our representatives abroad. I believe that Australia needs to have as much representation abroad as we can—within the need, of course, to be financially responsible—and I am very pleased that the Department of Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade is moving in the direction of co‐location with Canada of embassies and high commissions, so that in places where we are not able to have a stand‐alone mission, or where Canada feels that that is not possible, we are able to co‐locate missions with Canada. We are two middle‐sized countries and our interests, generally speaking, do not clash. I think it is infinitely preferable for us to have co‐located missions rather than no missions at all.

In recent visits abroad I have noticed that, with many of the new countries attaining independence, Australia has not been able to have resident diplomatic representation in their capitals. I believe that the cooperative arrangement that the department is endeavouring to pursue with Canada will be one means of bringing about cost‐effective resident representation for Australia in many of those countries. When we do have that kind of resident representation in countries, we are very well‐positioned to take advantage of trade opportunities. I want to commend the ministers and the parliamentary secretary for initiating this move.

There is an alternative available, of course—and I think we are also following it to an extent—and that is having mini‐embassies. Instead of having missions which have to have 20, 30 or 40 people on staff, we can have very small missions. With all the modern facilities and the communications capacity around these days, it is possible to have a small mission with an ambassador and maybe one or two staff, and when it is necessary to obtain advice from Canberra, it is only a computer, a fax or a phone call away.

I am a very strong advocate of resident representation of Australia in as many countries as possible. I think the department's co‐location with Canada idea is great and the mini‐embassy arrangement, maybe on the Slovenian model in Canberra, is desirable. But if it is not possible to have paid staff in the various capitals, then the proposal to have honorary consuls is a very good idea because it is important to provide the best possible services to Australia abroad. It is also important to realise that having local resident representation in countries and their capitals will put us in a very good position when we come to export goods to those countries.

The minister in his second reading speech also outlined the wonderful record of the government in encouraging Australia to become, and remain, a very good international citizen. The minister pointed out, when referring to the chemical weapons and nuclear safeguards acts, that it is highly unlikely that an inspection team will ever have to come to Australia to investigate another country's allegation that Australia was in breach of the convention but that, should this occur, representatives of the country making such an allegation would be extended the standard diplomatic privileges and immunities, along with other members of the inspection team. And that obviously is very positive.

The minister also pointed out that we have a well‐deserved reputation as a leading player in arms control. I must say that our predecessors also were very interested in this matter, and it is significant that arms control has been a bipartisan issue. But the new government, the new ministers and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs have obviously brought these matters into focus, and Australia is now widely recognised as having taken the lead internationally concerning arms control. Everyone would know that the efforts of this government in the international fora helped to bring to a conclusion the comprehensive test ban treaty. The international community has endeavoured over 20 years to achieve this, but Australia managed to do a tremendous lot to bring this to reality. In addition, over the past year, as the minister points out in his second reading speech, Australia has been one of the leaders internationally in gathering an adequate number of signatures to bring the chemical weapons convention into force.

Another thing I will mention very briefly is the very strong position taken by the government in relation to landmines. Landmines are completely uncivilised, and this government and the minister, through international fora, have taken a very strong stand. I am very pleased with the results that the advocacy by this government have produced internationally.

I will also briefly mention the Passports Act. It is very important to recognise that the issuing of passports is a vital role of the Department of Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and it is necessary that this facility be made available to Australian citizens. Of course, a passport is evidence of who a person is and it is evidence of citizenship, and it is therefore vital that Australian passports are only given to those people who are entitled to them. The bill tightens the provision in relation to the offence of making false statements concerning passport applications. As I have said previously, it adds the concept of recklessness as a mental element in the offence of making a false statement on a passport application or in support of such an application. I commend that element in particular to the Main Committee.

This is a very sensible omnibus bill. It changes a number of existing acts. The bill is largely of a technical nature, and I believe it will be supported in the Australian community. The sentiments which have brought about the framing of this bill are very positive, and the changes are necessary. I urge the Committee to support wholeheartedly the bill introduced to the parliament by the government. I thank the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Andrew, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDREW THOMSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my task to sum up a few of the remarks that have been made in the debate on the Foreign Affairs and Trade Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 .
—It will be a Churchillian effort!

—I do not think I have quite got Churchill's frame, but I am working my way towards it! At the appropriate time, I will move two further amendments to the bill. To summarise, it is plainly an omnibus bill that amends four different acts: the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act, the International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Act, the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation (Safeguards) Act and the Passports Act. As the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) pointed out, it deals with a spectrum of issues such as false passport applications, where it introduces the concept of recklessness into the offence of making a false declaration in applying for a passport and it strengthens the international nuclear safeguards standards.

SPEECH.PARA: I note there was some debate among members on issues of the environment that merge with issues of nuclear safeguards in this respect. This gives me the opportunity to put on record a defence of the newly appointed Ambassador for the Environment, Ms Meg McDonald. Her appointment was announced earlier this week. I thought it was rather churlishly criticised by representatives of those two very peculiar fringe‐dwelling parties, the Democrats and the Greens.

It has always amused me that people can be elected to parliament representing the Democrats on the basis that doubt is a legitimate philosophical posture. They think they are in the middle but, of course, as we all know—those of us in the mainstream—they are not in the middle; they are nowhere. As for Senator Bob Brown and the Greens—who would better be named, I think, the anti‐private enterprise party—using the cloak of environmental concern for what is basically a Marxist agenda, for him to say—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, the Liberal Party has the most environmental agenda in the parliament, or the coalition has.

—We do, as my colleague points out. But that said, for Senator Bob Brown to criticise the Ambassador for the Environment and say that she was more interested in economic issues than environmental ones is quite ridiculous. We all know that the environmental problems that we suffer on this planet will be solved, as they have been solved in the past, not with political rhetoric or an excess of international fora, but with technology, and technology is a product of nothing more than private enterprise. If he would come out of the closet and declare himself as nothing more than an opponent of private enterprise, it would serve this nation much better.

SPEECH.PARA: At this point, I thank all those who participated in the debate. It is nice to see, from time to time, some bipartisan or even non‐partisan sentiments being addressed. Occasionally, of course, it makes you nervous when you see the other side of the chamber agreeing with you. It reminds me of the old statement from Chairman Mao `When the fox seems friendly put another lock on the chicken coop.' In this case, I think we can celebrate some bipartisanship that has been displayed in the debate on this bill.

TITLE.XREF: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 June, on motion by Mr McGauran:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"consideration of the bill be deferred until a comprehensive inquiry is conducted into the operation of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and an assessment made as to the degree to which both the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory Governments are meeting their responsibilities to the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory in these matters".

Terms of reference have been released on a review that is proposed of the Aboriginal land rights act. It is worthwhile reading onto the record the terms of that review which are as follows. The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 commenced operation on 26 January 1977. The last general review was in 1983 and some important changes have been made to its provision since then. The review will examine and report on the operation of the act and suggest any areas for possible change, including recommending amendments where appropriate.

In particular, the review will consider: firstly, the effectiveness of the legislation achieving its purpose; secondly, the impact of the legislation in terms of its social, cultural and economic costs and benefits; thirdly, the operation of the exploration and mining provisions; fourthly, the operation of the Aboriginal benefits trust account, including the distribution of payments out of the trust account; fifthly, the operation of royalty associations, including their reporting requirements; sixthly, the question of the need for compulsory acquisition powers over Aboriginal land; seventhly, the application of Northern Territory laws to Aboriginal land; eighthly, the role, structure and resource needs of the land councils following the coming into effect of a sunset clause relating to land claims and, ninthly, any other matters relevant to the operation of the act.

The review will be required to report six months after it commences. It is not going to be a long review. That of itself worries me. I hope that it is not one of those reviews where the fix is already on, given the performance of this government in indigenous affairs since it came into office just over 18 months ago and the amendments that we now see to the Native Title Act 1993.

I fear, and my reservations are, that the fix is on to basically strip the land rights act in the Northern Territory of any of the powers that it gives indigenous people there.We on the opposition side will certainly be having a very close watching brief on that. Any amendments should be aimed at improving outcomes in the Northern Territory. They should not be aimed as a front to strip away indigenous rights. The act is working well. You have established land councils in the Northern Territory.

It is an honour and a privilege to have my colleague the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) here today. He actually introduced that 1986 bill when he was the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It is a landmark piece of legislation. I anticipate that my colleague will give some instances where all the Northern Territory government has done is just try to attack clauses in that bill and usurp the law of the land. It just loses time after time and has wasted millions of dollars in legal challenges.

The second part of my amendment is aimed at ensuring that the negotiations that have been undertaken between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory in relation to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1997 which is now before the parliament are honoured by the Northern Territory government. There is a history that is laid out in the second reading speech about these particular problems.

There is an excellent digest from the Parliamentary Library, prepared by Jennifer Norberry and dated 3 September 1997, which again contains a long history in relation to this. I take this opportunity to commend Jennifer Norberry and members of the Parliamentary Library. They provide excellent research services for us as a parliament but they are not acknowledged, in my opinion, as much as they should be. Jennifer Norberry in particular is a very professional officer in the Parliamentary Library, and in all my dealings with her I regard her as a thoroughly professional and decent person supporting us as parliamentarians. It again shows that we do have in the Public Service dedicated professionals committed to the public service. Too often we hear from this government that you have got to outsource and go out to private enterprise to get the best. I think the Parliamentary Library has the best, and Jennifer Norberry is amongst the best. I commend her again for this digest.

What we say is that there should be deferral of this bill because the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly was recently prorogued for territory elections and it is expected that the amendments to the Pastoral Land Act 1992, in the form of a new bill, will be introduced into the new assembly. We say that there are two reasons for the deferral of this: we want to see the Northern Territory assembly enact its legislation before we on this side approve this legislation, and also we think that there is a broader concern here anyway.

BREAK.PARA: What is the use of putting this amendment through if there is going to be a swag of other amendments to the land rights act coming as a result of the review? Let us do them in a package. It is not as if this problem is an urgent one. It is, in terms of its impact on indigenous people in the Northern Territory, but I would not be relying on the Northern Territory government acting in the interests of indigenous people in view of the hysteria that the current Chief Minister goes on with in relation to the Native Title Act when he has an act that is much stronger and there is development occurring in the Northern Territory.

There is not a lot I want to say. I know that my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne Ports will follow me. But basically it is worth quoting from what he said at the time of the introduction of the 1986 bill. I think it is better for me to quote him than for my colleague to be seen as issuing self‐serving statements. He had this to say, as is shown at page 3 of the digest:

Under the present Act it is possible for Aboriginals to claim title to stock routes and reserves, and a number of the claims that have yet to be heard and reported on by Aboriginal land commissioners are in respect of such stock routes and reserves.

Some practical problems have emerged. On the other hand, a claim to such lands may offer, to some Aboriginal groups living in the pastoral areas of the Northern Territory, the best or in some cases the only prospect of obtaining title to some of their traditional lands. On the other hand, to proceed to grant title to some of these areas—assuming that a land commissioner had so recommended—would result in the splitting of existing pastoral leases into two or more segments, with consequent disruption and costs for the pastoralist concerned.

Against this background, it has been the Government's position that it would be preferable, as a general rule, that claims to stock routes and reserves not proceed and that a program be developed, with the co‐operation of the Northern Territory Government and pastoralists, whereby excisions from pastoral leases to provide living areas for Aboriginal groups would be negotiated. Useful progress has been made in these negotiations. These negotiations are now well advanced in 40 cases, and actual title has been granted in 13 cases. There are some 61 applications at varying stages in the pipeline.

There are, however, some Aboriginal groups living in pastoral areas for whom the excisions program offers limited prospects and who may therefore, in view of the land councils, be seriously disadvantaged if they were forced to forgo the prospect of obtaining living areas on stock reserves. We have also been discussing these special cases with the Northern Territory Government.

I have now informed the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, the land councils and the Cattlemen's Association that the Commonwealth will proceed, in this Bill, with an amendment which will prevent a land commissioner from hearing claims to stock routes and reserves, unless a hearing has already commenced or unless the stock route or reserve is wholly encompassed in the overall area of land under claim. This is a significant concession.

In general, the provisions of the 1987 act commenced on royal assent. However, two of the sections it inserted into the principal act, subsections 52(d) and 52(e), were to come into operation on a date fixed by proclamation. These two subsections related to claims over stock routes and stock reserves. The proclamation was not made until February 1990, and it set a commencement date of 1 March 1990. There is some further explanation of that in the Bills Digest . There is one other part that I do want to quote. On page 4 it says:

The need for a statutory regime in the Northern Territory relating to Aboriginal community living areas on pastoral land was referred to in Minister Holding's speech above. It had been raised at least as early as the 1970s, and was addressed by Justice John Toohey in his 1983 report on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. Justice Toohey remarked in that report:

While the amount of land available for claim under the [Principal] Act is substantial, there are many Aboriginals to whom the benefits of the legislation are not available because their traditional country is on alienated land (mainly pastoral leases) which cannot be claimed. . .

Most of these communities have no security of title to the land on which they live and many are anxious for that security. Without it they do not qualify for some forms of government assistance and so are unable to improve their material conditions significantly. Understandably, governments are reluctant to spend substantial sums on improvements to land in which Aboriginals have no legal interest.

In 1989, an agreement was reached between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory, so this has a bit of a history. It appears to us on this side that we really should be deferring this. Let the Northern Territory government come up and enact the legislation, and in conjunction with the review we can look at this in a wholesale way. I think it is absurd continually to have these amendments. There is no urgency for these particular amendments to be processed at this point of time, especially when we hope a review is going to report within six months of the person being appointed.

But I do reiterate what I started with. I have major concerns about the goodwill and good faith of this government when it comes to indigenous Australians. I do not say that in relation to a number of members on the other side of the House. I believe that there are number of members on the other side of the House who have an empathy and an understanding of indigenous people, who actually have lived with them on the ground, who understand that there has been coexistence, and who respect traditional customs and law of indigenous Australia. My criticisms are not aimed at individual members on the other side.

I have been shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs for 18 months, and I believe that there is now a body of factual material in the public domain that shows that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has no empathy or understanding when it comes to dealing with indigenous Australians. He is in a time warp, and has a one‐dimensional, white, Anglo‐Saxon, Protestant view of the world. His definition of `for all of us' is obvious from the way he has practised it in the last 18 months, and from the legislation that he has sponsored into the parliament purporting to be amendments to the Native Title Act 1993. It is not legislation that a Prime Minister of this country should be sponsoring if he is genuinely acting on his election commitment to represent all of us. It is obvious that his definition of `all of us' is `some of us', and it does not include indigenous Australians.

Instead of growing in the office, we have seen him diminish in the office. I would not mind if it was just him diminishing in the office, but he is diminishing all of us. He is diminishing the nation. He is on the path of turning this country into a pariah in terms of the international community because of the way the government has changed direction in dealing with indigenous people. These are points I make against the Prime Minister of this country, because I think he has been a disappointment in this area.

I am not saying it is easy. There is prejudice and there is fear out there. That is why I have the respect that I do for the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating. As a matter of record, it is well‐known that I did not support him in either of the leadership challenges against Bob Hawke but, in my opinion, he grew in stature in the office of Prime Minister. He showed leadership and took on the forces of prejudice in this country in his enactment and his sponsoring of the passage of the Native Title Act 1993, without the cooperation of the then opposition. The tragedy for this nation is that indigenous Australians have been used as political footballs by this government since this government lost that 1993 election—the election that it should never have lost.

Cross‐party support in indigenous affairs and in immigration went out the window because the then opposition was desperate. They saw power within their reach in 1993 and it eluded them. That is why we had this response by the now Prime Minister, when he was a mere member of his caucus, that forced the then Leader of the Opposition, Dr John Hewson, and the then opposition parties, not to engage the government in debate and not to engage in a constructive all party response to the High Court's decision on Mabo. That is all right for opposition but it is not all right for government.

It is not all right for the Prime Minister of this nation to set up indigenous people, and that is what has happened from the first announcement of this cabinet that it had appointed a special auditor into ATSIC, which was subsequently held to be illegal three to nil by the Federal Court—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The honourable member for Banks clearly knows that he is now wandering away from the legislation before us in this chamber dealing with amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill and I ask that you keep him on that tack.
—There is no point of order. It is a broad ranging debate but I will ask the member for Banks to do his best to stick strictly to the bill before the house.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the basis of my broad ranging remarks are that I have moved a second reading amendment that basically says that we want deferral of these amendments until the review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. My suspicion, in terms of how this government will handle the land rights legislation, is directly as a result of observing this Prime Minister in action—firstly as Leader of the Opposition and now as Prime Minister. In my view that is where I am trying to link them together because there is no need for this. I do not trust the Northern Territory government to enact anything that is beneficial to indigenous Australians, and that is why in my amendment I say that this parliament should—because we have a special responsibility under the 1967 referendum to legislate for the benefit of indigenous Australians—let the Northern Territory government enact its part of the bargain first.

BREAK.PARA: Let us look at this review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. If it is to be an honest, open and transparent review, and the fix is not on, then we on this side of the House would be quite happy to support these agreements. Agreements are about both sides delivering. I understand that there is some cynicism about that but the great tragedy is that trust has gone out the window. Trust has gone out the window because indigenous Australians see themselves under attack. We are all under attack. We are all diminished and it is unnecessary.

I finish by saying that there is no urgency on this bill. With the way this government has the Senate program at the moment, that is not a high priority matter. I would urge the relevant minister to accept the second reading amendment. With the other amendments in the last session of the parliament to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act we engaged in a very cooperative approach. That legislation had been waiting for some time to be dealt with by this parliament. I approached the minister's office, we had a number of hand‐backs, and it went through in the same week. That is the way we should be dealing with indigenous affairs in this parliament because these issues are above partisan politics. These issues are not helped when we start to divide our community, and feed into the prejudices of our community, by holding indigenous people up as a political tool and a political football. I commend the amendment to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment, Mr Deputy Speaker, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise not to support the amendment proposed by the member for Banks (Mr Melham) to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1997 . Before he leaves the chamber let me say that there was a memorandum of understanding between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory dated 7 September 1989 where it was agreed that certain land would be scheduled as Aboriginal land, that the territory would pass legislation allowing for pastoral lease excisions for community living areas, and that the Commonwealth would pass amendments to ensure the remaining stock route claims would lapse. The legislative action, which was introduced by the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), did not achieve that aim when he introduced the legislation, and I can quote him on that a bit later on.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to support the government's legislation, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1997, which provides for the disposal of certain Aboriginal land claims over stock routes and stock reserves, and the removal of technicalities associated with section 67A of the principal act.

Clause 2 of the bill is the commencement provision which provides that the amendments contained in the bill commence on proclamation. However, if no proclamation has been made within 12 months from when this legislation receives royal assent, then the schedule commences the day after the end of that 12-month period.

Items 1 and 2 of schedule 1 amend section 67A of the principal act. This is the most important amendment as it is this section which provides that where the land is subject to a land claim under the act no other interest connected with the land may be considered. It is this section that has caused concern in the territory regarding future land use.

Subsection 67A(5) of the act sets out conditions where a land claim will be regarded as being disposed of. Currently, a land claim is disposed of if the claim is withdrawn, granted, or if a decision is made to reject the claim.

Item 2 of schedule 1 inserts a new subsection 67A(6). This subsection increases the circumstances in which a land claim will be taken to have been disposed of. This will occur where the claim has involved a stock route or stock reserve or where the Aboriginal land commissioner had not begun an inquiry into a land claim by 1 March 1990.

There are two other amendments to the act which territorians will welcome. These will ensure that if the Aboriginal Land Commission is unable to make a ruling regarding traditional owners, or if the claim was lodged after the sunset clause, then the claim can finally be disposed of.

Since this Commonwealth act came into operation over the Northern Territory in 1977, a total of 60 separate parcels of land have been scheduled. This act has provided a mechanism for over half the territory to be granted or be under claim by Aboriginal territorians. The title to this land is generally held by an Aboriginal land trust in fee simple, which makes it the most complete and secure form of title to land.

Around 700,000 square kilometres of territory is currently held by Aboriginal interests. When enacted in 1977, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 provided for the immediate transfer of 258,000 square kilometres of land for Aboriginal people. The act also provides the mechanism for the grant of traditional Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory to land trusts that hold title for traditional Aboriginal owners.

BREAK.PARA: Land claims are heard before an Aboriginal land commissioner who, after examination of the claimant case, makes a recommendation to the Commonwealth minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs who then has the discretion to accept or reject the recommendation.

As well as specifying what land is potentially available for claim, the land rights act also excludes certain land from claim; for example, roads are excluded. Following the enactment of the land rights act in 1997, a number of land claims were lodged over areas of land which included stock routes. Stock routes were not specifically excluded from a land claim in the act. A group of cases in the 1980s established that land claims could indeed be made over stock routes and stock reserves under the provisions of the act. This is not what the legislative draftsmen of the Northern Territory government had intended, and difficulties have since arisen over the status of claim on stock routes and reserves.

In 1986 the federal Labor government introduced amendments to the act in an attempt to clarify the position regarding stock routes. These amendments, subsequently passed by the parliament, provided that with some exemptions the Aboriginal Land Commissioner should be unable to hear a land claim over a stock route or stock reserve, but did not allow for the claim to be disposed of. That has subsequently caused all the uncertainty.

In 1986 the then Labor Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), who is present with us today, when discussing the amendment in this place noted that the act presented some technical problems in dealing with claims over stock routes. He said that claims over stock routes would, and I quote:
. . . result in the splitting of existing pastoral leases into two or more segments, with consequent disruption and costs for the pastoralists concerned.

Against this background, it has been the Government's position that it would be preferable, as a general rule, that claims to stock routes and reserves not proceed and that a program be developed, with the co‐operation of the Northern Territory Government and pastoralists, whereby excisions from pastoral leases to provide living areas for Aboriginal groups would be negotiated.
That is recorded in the Hansard of 22 October 1986.

Between 1987 and 1989, the Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments negotiated a statutory framework for the granting of Aboriginal community living areas on pastoral land. In 1989 a memorandum of understanding which had three parts was signed by the parties. I think this may even have been signed with Mr Tuxworth at Yulara when the member for Melbourne Ports was the minister. There is nothing on the Hansard which would tell us that, but from memory I think it was he who negotiated with the former Northern Territory Chief Minister Ian Tuxworth at Yulara. He may correct me if I am wrong.

It allowed for certain land to be scheduled as Aboriginal land. The Northern Territory government was to legislate for the establishment of community living areas on pastoral leases, and the Commonwealth would pass amendments that would ensure that all remaining stock route claims would lapse. That was seven years ago.

As agreed, the Northern Territory enacted legislation establishing Aboriginal community living areas on pastoral land. This legislation enabled certain Aboriginal people to apply for community living areas on pastoral properties, and a successful application resulted in a grant of freehold title to the Aboriginal group. However, the Commonwealth's amendments to the land rights act were ineffective.

The amendments to the act meant that while on the whole the Aboriginal Land Commissioner could not hear particular land claims involving stock routes and stock reserves, the legislation did not dispose of these claims. As a result of section 67A of the act, land under claim cannot be dealt with by the Northern Territory government. In other words, while the Northern Territory government has fulfilled its part of the 1989 agreement, the Commonwealth has not delivered on what it had agreed.

Just now the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) was saying how concerned he was about the interests and the actions of the Northern Territory government, and saying that he did not trust this Commonwealth government in dealing with these questions. Yet this has been on the record here since 1989 and it is still outstanding. Now the opposition has asked to defer it until such time as the inquiry takes six months to evaluate the Northern Territory land rights act. The review announcement has been made, but no chairman has been appointed as yet.

When Justice Toohey reviewed it in 1983, it took the Labor government four years to get the amendments into legislation, and then they were false: they did not work. The Labor Party is now asking for further delays to resolving the section about stock routes, when it agreed seven years ago that it should happen. That is what I would like to say to the honourable member for Banks. It was an arrangement made for living areas, and Aboriginal communities got the living areas, but we still have not got the stock route section resolved.

Because it goes into a trust, the land council refused to withdraw the stock route claims. As a result there is still a level of uncertainty over the status of the land under claims seven years later. There are Aboriginal communities out there that want to do something. They want to try and get a bit of economic development, but there are still problems.

The Northern Territory government has been trying to get the Commonwealth to honour its side of the agreement since 1990. In 1995, after further negotiations between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory government, agreement was reached that the Labor government would amend the land rights act again to ensure that the stock route and stock reserve claims would be disposed of. Notwithstanding the fact that the territory had already fulfilled its side of the 1989 agreement, it was resolved that the territory would amend its community living areas legislation. The NT Pastoral Land Act 1992 would be amended to expedite the granting of living areas to Aboriginal people by the tribunal. However, the Commonwealth conceded that the territory would do this only once the Commonwealth stock routes amendments we are debating today were passed.

The Northern Territory Legislative Assembly was prorogued on 12 August in 1997 for the territory elections last month. The amendments to the NT Pastoral Land Act 1992 subsequently lapsed and will be introduced in the form of a new bill in the next parliamentary session. A review of the Aboriginal land rights act is imminent and I welcome the government's decision to investigate the relevance of the act 20 years after its introduction. I am particularly pleased to note that the terms of reference include a look at the role and structure of Aboriginal land councils, particularly in light of the sunset clause that came into effect this year.
It came as no surprise to Territorians that on the very day the sunset clause came into effect, the Northern and Central land councils slapped claims on virtually all remaining land in the territory.

I am for Aboriginal self‐determination, but I am yet to be convinced that the mere act of granting land will improve the living standards of Aboriginal Territorians. At the risk of sounding cynical, I fail to see how claims over areas like national parks, Alice to Darwin railway reserves, future roadhouse sites, land set aside for police purposes and racecourses, plus a litany of rivers, roads, stock routes and parts of the seabed are aimed at improving the lives of Aboriginal people. For many Territorians it simply looks like a last‐minute land grab.

I wait with interest and some trepidation to see how these claims are settled. I am also interested in the outcomes of claims made under the Native Title Act that exist over Darwin, Alice Springs, assorted pastoral properties and parts of the Arafura Sea to the north. The people in the territory are hopeful that there will be bipartisan support for the amendments to the Native Title Act in order to restore certainty to tenure.

As already stated, I am in favour of self‐determination for Aboriginal territorians but the amount of land held as freehold by Aboriginal Territorians raises serious questions about future land use and management. There are concerns about the ability for the territory government to manage its land. I know the territory government is concerned about the lack of ability to acquire interests in land, short of freehold, for essential public purposes. There is also a degree of uncertainty regarding the application of territory laws on Aboriginal land and the ability to claim public facilities. The difficulties of administrating this Aboriginal land rights act are brought home by the current case before the Federal Court in which the Northern Land Council is challenging the application of territory laws on Aboriginal land. The Northern Land Council claims that by virtue of the land granted under the land rights act they are now entitled to stop people entering, or fishing in, the waters off the top end of the Territory. This application is in several parts and it is important that members understand the dire consequences for the territory if this action is successful.

First, the application is asking for the court to validate the claim that the Northern Land Council has the right to exclude people from entering or fishing in the intertidal zone off Aboriginal land. It goes on to argue that since the NLC did not give its consent, the Northern Territory government has no power to issue licenses under the Fisheries Act in respect of these waters. On this basis, all previously issued licences are invalid and therefore entry into these waters is considered an actionable trespass on Aboriginal land.

The second part of the claim seeks to restrain the Northern Territory government from issuing further licences in respect of these waters. There are also claims for damages, costs and other relief that the court thinks fit. This action, if successful, will call into question the ability of the Northern Territory government to govern for Territorians. The Northern Territory government already has concerns about its ability to acquire land for public works for future generations and this court action only substantiates these concerns.

The land councils enjoy exclusive freehold on land granted to them under the Commonwealth act. As more and more land is granted to land councils, the Northern Territory government loses its ability to plan for schools and hospitals for future population growth. Naturally, I am alarmed by the prospect that territory laws could be ruled invalid over Aboriginal land. I do not think for a moment the NLC has taken this step in an attempt to protect fish stocks or the marine habitat. There is no mention in the claim of any environmental concerns or sacred sites in the area. This is a blatantly hostile action by the NLC and an action designed to test the limits of the courts and the goodwill of territorians.

Recreational fishermen already pay for a permit to enter Aboriginal land to access fishing grounds. This is on top of the money they pay the Northern Territory government for a fishing licence. Now the NLC wants to prohibit the territory government from levying a licence fee and have its own collection regime. In my opinion, this revenue would be better spent by the Territory government on fisheries management for the whole territory, rather than ending up in the pockets of a few Aboriginal activists. The Amateur Fishing Association of the Northern Territory has worked tirelessly with the government to implement some of the best fisheries management strategies in the world. I share their outrage at this action by the Northern Land Council.

Aboriginals need to be able to develop land in order to improve their standard of living, something which is simply not happening. It is unclear as to whether this is due to the difficulties of dealing with land councils or the uncertainty of laws governing the land. The issue of development is one that we need to address urgently. All the Aboriginal territorians I have met want economic development for their people, something they have not achieved by the mere fact that they have secured the land. The actions of the land councils are hindering Aboriginal economic development and territorians are becoming frustrated and impatient with the state of Aboriginal affairs and land tenure.

The claim by the Northern Land Council to invalidate territory laws over Aboriginal land is a serious abuse of their charter. Another disturbing aspect of this action is that the NLC does not have support for it from all Aboriginal communities in the Top End. Some Aboriginals I have met blame the political agenda of the land councils for the level of ill‐feeling some territorians have towards normal hard‐working Aboriginals. There is a misconception among residents of southern states that the objectives of Aboriginal Australians and the Aboriginal land councils are the same. Well, let me tell you they are not. The land councils are not acting in the best interests of Aboriginal territorians.

The very noticeable lack of support from some quarters has called into question the very nature of Aboriginal representation in the territory. Every time I go bush I hear stories of neglect and contempt by the land councils and by some ATSIC representatives for the local communities. The only answer is decentralisation of land councils. There are countless examples of Aboriginal communities refusing to deal with the land councils and, indeed, some are trying to form breakaway land councils of their own. I would be happy to take the honourable member for Banks to those communities any time he likes. I would be happy to arrange the trip.
The Northern and Central land councils willingly accept—in fact, demand—millions and millions of taxpayers' money every year to fund their activities, money they should spend on education, health—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. There has been a fair amount of capacity for members to be wide‐ranging in their contributions on this debate and a fair bit of latitude has been allowed by deputy speakers and by both sides. However, I do think the member is straying far beyond any stock route that relates to this particular piece of legislation.
—I thank the honourable member for Bruce. The honourable member for the Northern Territory will stay on route.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I need to continue in terms of the amendment the member for Banks introduced which had wide‐ranging—
—I do endorse what the honourable member is saying. The second reading amendment does broaden it considerable.
—Yes. I have not got very long to go—
—And he tried to use your time up.

—I do not mind. As I said, the Northern and Central land councils are willing to accept, in fact demand, millions and millions of taxpayers' dollars anyway. If we, as a government, could bypass the large land councils and give financial assistance to smaller land councils run by community elders with a better understanding of their community needs, all Aboriginals would be better off.

BREAK.PARA: I have always been a supporter of smaller land councils, and it is actions like those of the Northern Land Council that bring home the reality of how out of touch the larger councils in the communities are. As I said earlier, the last review was done in 1983 by Justice Toohey. It took four years to implement some of his recommendations. Therefore, I do not believe that we need another four years not to pass the amendments introduced by the government. The amendment of the honourable member for Banks should be defeated, because you are virtually saying that you want to renege on an agreement you made seven years ago. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was fascinated by the speech of my colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1997 .
—He's a nice guy.

—Yes, indeed. If you listened closely not merely to what he was saying in his speech but also to the very terminology that he used, you will see why my colleague the member for Banks (Mr Melham) has suggested that what is needed is a thoroughgoing review of all of this. I would say this to the honourable member for the Northern Territory. Throughout his speech there were two significant things that come automatically to many members of the coalition in the Northern Territory: that is, he continually referred to territorians `and' Aboriginals. I would hope that, by now, whatever view you took in terms of the state, a significant percentage of Australians who are of Aboriginal origin have lived in the Northern Territory, and their families have lived there, for far longer than the more recent settlers have.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter almost of psychology that the member for the Northern Territory instinctively falls into a use of language whereby he talks about Territorians as if they are a different group of people and excludes, and has another characterisation for, the indigenous people of the Northern Territory, who would have far greater claim to be called Territorians—because they and their families were there long before many of the people who are now there ever thought of settling.

I do not resile from my comments in the speech I made in respect of pastoral properties. What I said then was accurate. It was accurate then and it is accurate now. I am concerned, when I look at the kind of legislation that has been introduced into the parliament as a dimension of the argument which now goes on across Australia about the future of pastoral leases and the rights of our indigenous people, that there is a major debate about to be adjourned.

Let me say this: as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs between March 1983 and 1987, I spent a great deal of time in the Northern Territory, and I do not think there was any significant political leader or any significant Aboriginal group that I did not sit down and talk to. I am bound to say that, in terms of the Northern Territory government's involvement in the practice of this legislation, I welcomed that. Legislation followed the Woodward commission, which was picked up and responded to by the Whitlam government, but the actual legislation was put through by a then coalition government led by Malcolm Fraser.

The attitude that Malcolm Fraser took and now takes in respect of the rights of indigenous people is to his everlasting credit. His views on the racist attitude of the then government of South Africa on apartheid were fairly exceptional at the time he was Prime Minister, having regard to the coalition. He was a great credit to a party that now seems to have shifted its focus.

There was not a single land grant that I made as minister—and I was bound as a matter of courtesy to notify the Northern Territory government of the day—which was not the subject of immediate legal challenge, which inevitably finished in them losing. The costs to the citizens of the Northern Territory, and I include the Aboriginal people, were enormous. The course of confrontation that took place on so many issues still is built into the psychology of many of the people in the Northern Territory. It is exemplified when the member for the Northern Territory gets up in this House and, without even thinking about it, uses the terminology `Territorians' which means `us' and `Aboriginals' which means `them'. There comes a time in the history of this nation when that terminology has to cease.

These expressions and the kinds of approaches that are now being taken by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) are going to recreate problems which I thought many of us had solved—for instance, the legislation on the upgrading of pastoral leases that is contemplated around Australia. I do not want to go into details. I simply want to make this point. While I was a minister and land grants were taking place, there was continual misrepresentation by members of what is now the coalition, about the purpose of that. There was substantial legal challenge which was, by its nature, intended to divide the dominant white community from the indigenous people in terms of political and social structures.

It even got to the stage where a formal Liberal member of this parliament, who had mining interests on an area of land in the Northern Territory that could not possibly be developed—but it did have ore underneath it—left mining machinery on the land of a traditional owner. This caused that man great illness. It was the only occasion on which I granted a title to land without informing the Northern Territory government. I did that on the basis of legal advice because, once the land was vested, it was beyond challenge. I had to deliver the title in the Darwin hospital. There was a sense of outrage because they had not been notified. It was the only way we could get the machinery off the land.

I had hope for this parliament and, more importantly, for this nation. Like all members, I go to the citizenship ceremonies and, on many occasions, I am accompanied by members of the Liberal coalition, mainly state members. There is one thing we agree about: this is a multicultural nation. We all make speeches saying, `Welcome to the family.' This legislation is now before parliament—and the second reading was taken up today by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and other speakers from the opposition. We are a multicultural nation and, if this legislation and this government's attitude continues, we will be a multicultural nation in name only. You are only a truly multicultural nation when you include the indigenous people of Australia within the fabric of our culture, which builds on their traditions and relationships with the land.

The attitude of the Northern Territory government has basically been schizophrenic. I used to get off aeroplanes to be greeted by people holding up placards saying, `Rights for whites.' When you asked them how long they had been in the Northern Territory, they would say five years, three years, six months.

There comes a time in this nation where we have to come together as a people. I must say I find it fascinating, when there are people with the attitude that there are Territorians and Aboriginals, that when in my state you see the advertisement saying, `Come to the Northern Territory,' what you see is photographs of land which is Aboriginal land and where titles have passed. You see Aboriginal drawings and Aboriginal paintings. When I go there, as I have been recently to visit Aboriginal relatives, what do I find? I find tourism booming. I find lines of people from all over the world waiting to look at rock art sites, which are whole galleries going back 20,000, 30,000 and—in some cases—60,000 years. They are part of the heritage of all Australians: they are part of my heritage; Mr Deputy Speaker, they are part of your heritage.

The thing that staggers me is that there are these problems, but you can only solve them if you start on the basis of treating Aboriginal people as equals. They can only be solved if we are able to intellectually and mentally cut across some of our own traditions. They have survived and the conditions under which they live in many of the southern states are much worse than the situation prevailing in the Northern Territory.

But if you stop and think about it, there is a perception and a relationship and a spiritual belief related to what they see as their country. I know young Aboriginal men of great skills who, if you were to meet them today, are very much Australians. But they go back to go through ceremonies which are buried in the mists of time in order to take their role as leaders of their own community.

Let me say on the basis of much experience that, despite all of the things that have occurred to them, there is still a generosity of spirit amongst Aboriginal people which will enable us—we only have to reach out—to share their perception of our land and their land, which is the land of all of us. We only have to look. It is only in the course of the last 10 years that the real history of Aboriginal people has been written.

They fought for their land, as they were entitled to.They were massacred in many places, and we cannot undo history. That is our history and we have to face up to it. But we have to face up to it by recognising the indigenous culture and the rights of indigenous people. Land councils have made mistakes; they will have to make a lot more mistakes in order to catch up with the mistakes that have been made by successive governments in Australia, both federal and state.

It is time now to pause. We have now got different approaches. The suggestion made by my colleague the member for Banks and shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs has much merit. I think we are going to be engaged, unfortunately, in a debate following the Wik legislation, which is by its very nature divisive and which will not enlarge the reputation of Australia in the eyes of the world. I am bound to say this. I had two farmers come to see me as part of a delegation from the National Farmers Federation. They were thoroughly decent, honest Australians who had a real affection and concern for their land. What surprised me and what angered me was that they had been lied to by their own leaders. Their land was not under threat or anything like it.

How can land be under threat, when the actual passages of the High Court judgment say that native title means no more than the right in some cases to go onto pastoral leases for the purposes of forage or for the purposes of visiting sacred sites for spiritual reasons? Nobody told them that. They sat there—as I say, decent, honest, hardworking Australians who had been lied to by their leaders, by the whipping up of the view that the Wik decision threatened the rights of pastoralists around Australia. That is nonsense. There is no way, in my view, that on an intelligent appraisal of the implications of the Wik judgment and the Mabo judgment, with less talk about adventurous courts, as a parliament we cannot work our way through this in a way which heals this nation and which does not divide it. I do not believe in legislation which deprives one group of a title which the High Court of Australia has recognised, which extinguishes their potential to make claims, in order to strengthen, at the cost of the taxpayers of Australia, the rights of some people holding pastoral leases, many of whom do not even live in Australia.

It is the role of the government—any government, irrespective of its basic political attitude—where there are divisions in this nation to heal them, not to exacerbate them. There will always be conflicting interests in our own community between some manufacturers and government policy, between some groups of workers and their employers. There is no future in using the legislative power of the Commonwealth to extinguish the rights of one group of people in order to strengthen and give additional rights to people who have only got, for example, pastoral leases. There is a very real difference in freehold title.

There is some talk about claims that, in the eyes of the honourable member for the Northern Territory, are unworthy claims. On the basis of fairly lengthy experience as a minister for Aboriginal affairs, I think there is one thing that you can always work on: if you keep any group of people outside the framework of your concepts of inclusiveness, and they are then given a right to claim, they will often make what can be talked about in legal terms as try‐ons. The way that is prevented is by discussion across the table by ministers, who have got to say, as I had to say on many occasions, `It is not on.' In any group of people who have gone through the deprivation that our indigenous people have gone through, when they create structures, there will be try‐ons. There will be try‐ons with the minister. Make no mistake about that.

Therefore, I believe the time will come when Australia will be judged in the eyes of the world about the way we handle these problems. The question of apartheid in South Africa was not just an issue for the South African government. There are people in Asia who do not think very highly of Australia and say so. Do we think that some of those leaders are not going to use an attitude that has, I think, been mistakenly taken in terms of the way in which we treat the claims of our indigenous people? I think it is time for everybody to take three deep breaths and to not go down a track which will exacerbate the problems that already exist in this area. I am happy to finish on the note that I support the amendments moved by the honourable member for Banks. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence for about 60 seconds to hopefully conclude the debate on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1997 in this chamber. I briefly mention that, as a seconder of the amendment, I think the amendment makes sense. What we are talking about here is a need to defer consideration of the amendments to this legislation while the review of the principal act occurs. Wide ranging debate on the whole issue of indigenous affairs in this country in the current circumstances we face has occurred through this bill and through other bills before the parliament. I think, in those circumstances, six months will not be a problem. While those issues are under consideration matters such as this can wait.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to take issue with some of the issues raised by the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) but, in order to facilitate the operation of this chamber, I think I will do that on another occasion. In conclusion, as well as supporting the amendment, I move:
That further proceedings be conducted in the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
